metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Maharashtra Sugar Mills Ltd.

facts.text: The assessee is Ms. Maharashtra Sugar Mills Ltd., a limited company carrying on business of manufacture of sugar from sugar cane. It owns extensive lands in which sugar cane is grown and used for manufacture.
The relevant assessment year is 1957-58, corresponding to account year ending 30-9-1956.
The finding of the Tribunal is that the cultivation of sugar cane and the manufacture of sugar by the assessee company constitute one single and indivisible business.
The assessee company is managed by managing agents paid remuneration per agreement, roughly 10 percent of profits. For the year, entitled to Rs. 4,86,228/- as commission.
In assessment, assessee claimed full deduction of Rs. 4,86,228/- under s.10(2)(xv) as expenditure wholly for business.
Income-tax Officer disallowed Rs. 1,26,359/- on ground it relates to managing agency commission for sugar cane cultivation part.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner concurred with ITO.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld assessee's plea, allowed full deduction under s.10(2)(xv), rejected Rule 23 applicability.
High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 83 of 1962, agreeing with Tribunal, answered question in favour of assessee on 22-9-1967.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of this case the Department could disallow a sum of Rs. 1,26,359/-, a portion of the managing agency commission paid by the assessee company for the assessment year 1957-58 in computing the income from business of the assessee company.

petitioner_arguments.text: Assessee's business consisted of two parts: cultivation of sugar cane (agricultural operation, income not exigible to tax) and manufacture of sugar. Expenditure on agricultural part not deductible.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Only expenditure on taxable business activity deductible

petitioner_arguments.text: Rule 23 of the Rules framed under the Act applicable to split up the commission.

respondent_arguments.text: Entire managing agency commission deductible under s.10(2)(xv) as cultivation and manufacture one single indivisible business.

court_reasoning.text: Finding that cultivation and manufacture constitute one single indivisible business is finding of fact, not challenged.

To determine deductibility under Act, examine relevant provisions; no equitable considerations in taxing statute. s.10(2)(xv) mandates deduction of expenditure laid out wholly and exclusively for business purpose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fact that income from part of business not taxable irrelevant.

court_reasoning.text: Managing agency commission laid out for purpose of the business.
Rule 23 not applicable: pertains to computing taxable portion where business partly agricultural; managing agency commission not expenditure as cultivator.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule 23(1) last part bars further deduction for cultivator expenditures, but commission not such.

holdings.text: Entire managing agency commission deductible under s.10(2)(xv) as expenditure wholly for business, despite part relating to non-taxable agricultural activity in integrated business.
Rule 23 not applicable to managing agency commission.

precedents_cited.case_name: S.A.S.S. Chellappa Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Interest paid on borrowings used in money-lending business, even if leading to agricultural lands received in repayment, deductible under s.10(2)(iii).

precedents_cited.case_name: Salt and Industries Agencies Ltd., Bombay v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City
precedents_cited.relevance: Managing agent's commission concerns overall profits, not split by location; taxable even if managed company's profits partly non-taxable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. C. Parakh & Co. (India) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Entire managing agency commission deductible against Indian profits even if business in multiple places including foreign; one business for s.10.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. Indian Bank Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Interest on borrowings for securities with tax-free interest fully deductible under s.10(2)(iii); no apportionment; adhere to s.10(2)(xv) language.

precedents_cited.case_name: Badridas Daga v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Ratio does not bear on issue.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference under s.66(1); computation of business profits under s.10; deduction for business expenditure under s.10(2)(xv); definition of agricultural income under s.2(1).

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Rules, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Method for computing taxable income where partially agricultural; no further deduction for cultivator expenditures; not applicable to managing commission.

outcome.summary: The appeal by the Department is dismissed, upholding the High Court and Tribunal that the entire managing agency commission is deductible under s.10(2)(xv).

key_quotes.text: The mandate of s.10(2)(xv) is plain and unambiguous. Undoubtedly the allowance claimed in this case was laid out or expended for the purpose of the business carried on by the assessee.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning for allowing full deduction.

key_quotes.text: The fact that the income arising from a part of that business is not exigible to tax under the Act is not a relevant circumstance.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects Department's contention on non-taxable part.

key_quotes.text: Equitable considerations are wholly out of place in construing the provisions of a taxing statute.
key_quotes.speaker: court
